results.title: Biden Rattles U.K. With His Afghanistan Policy
results.abstract: Britain was the second-largest supplier of troops to Afghanistan, and the United States’ rapid withdrawal from the country has left some embittered.

results.title: To China, Afghan Fall Proves U.S. Hubris. It Also Brings New Dangers.
results.abstract: The Taliban’s return to power is no victory for Beijing, which faces the threat of extremism and an American military no longer bogged down by the “war on terror.”
results.byline: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers

multimedia.caption: A Taliban fighter in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Wednesday. China has been scrambling to judge how the American defeat in Afghanistan could reshape the contest between the world’s two great powers.
multimedia.copyright: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times

results.title: How Haiti Was Devastated by Two Natural Disasters in Three Days
results.abstract: The impact of a magnitude-7.2 earthquake on Saturday was magnified Monday by heavy rains and wind from Grace, then a tropical depression, which would soon strengthen into a tropical storm.
results.byline: By Tim Wallace, Ashley Wu and Jugal K. Patel

results.title: Taliban Promise Peace, but Doubt and Fear Persist
results.abstract: In their first statement since taking control, the Taliban hinted at a rule unlike their brutal regime a generation ago, trying to placate skeptics.
results.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Richard Pérez-Peña
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

results.title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Students Over ‘Advocating Terrorism’
results.abstract: The student union leaders, who were detained under the national security law, had expressed sympathy for a man who stabbed a police officer before killing himself.

multimedia.caption: Li Kwai-Wah, a senior superintendent in the police’s National Security Department, said at a news briefing on Wednesday that the student union’s language “rationalizes, beautifies and glorifies terrorism.”
multimedia.copyright: Isaac Lawrence/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: For Afghan Women, Taliban Stir Fears of Return to a Repressive Past
results.abstract: Since the U.S. ousted the Taliban, women and girls have rejoined society in ways that would have been unimaginable under their rule. Now those gains are threatened.

des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

results.title: The Afghan president who fled the country is now in the U.A.E.
results.abstract: The whereabouts Ashraf Ghani, whose departure from Afghanistan last weekend sped the government’s collapse, had been a matter of speculation for days.
results.byline: By Marc Santora, Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Nossiter

multimedia.caption: “If I had stayed, countless of my countrymen would be martyred and Kabul would face destruction,” President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan wrote on social media on Sunday.
multimedia.copyright: Sajjad Hussain/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

results.title: Chaos spreads outside Kabul’s airport as the Taliban try to control crowds.
results.abstract: The U.S. military has established control inside Kabul’s international airport. But the roads leading to the facility, where there are growing crowds and mayhem, are controlled by the Taliban.

results.title: Blindsided Abroad: Vaccinated But Testing Positive on a Trip to Europe
results.abstract: The prevalence of the Delta variant means many travelers, including those who are vaccinated, are facing sickness, quarantines and delayed returns.

multimedia.caption: April DeMuth and her partner, Warren Watson, at their home in Hilton Head, S.C. They got sick on their Greek vacation, and had to be quarantined. “We had our vaccinations cards, we felt healthy, we’re in our 50s, it really didn’t occur to us that we had Covid.”
multimedia.copyright: Adam Kuehl for The New York Times

results.title: India says it will prioritize Hindus and Sikhs for emergency visas to Afghans.

results.title: Haiti Quake Toll Leaps to Nearly 2,000 Dead as Rain Pelts Survivors
results.abstract: The new casualty figures from Saturday’s quake, including 10,000 injured, come as victims struggled with a storm deluge that could complicate relief efforts.
results.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Constant Méheut

multimedia.caption: Sheltering from Tropical Storm Grace on Monday in Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti. The authorities said that the downpour was worsening the situation for those displaced by the quake two days earlier.
multimedia.copyright: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times

results.title: Maki Kaji, the ‘Godfather of Sudoku,’ Is Dead at 69
results.abstract: Mr. Kaji, a university dropout, turned a numbers game into one of the world’s most popular logic puzzles.
results.byline: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Hisako Ueno

results.title: George W. Bush says the events in Afghanistan fill him ‘with deep sadness.’
results.abstract: The former president, who ordered the invasion of Afghanistan that drove the Taliban from power two decades ago, said the U.S. had a “responsibility” to its Afghan allies.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
